revisions.*: Because "rvslots" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used.

{{Italic title}} {{Taxobox | image = Suillus viscidus.jpg | image_width = 235px | regnum = [[Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Boletales]] | familia = [[Suillaceae]] | genus = ''[[Suillus]]'' | species = '''''S. viscidus''''' | binomial = ''Suillus viscidus'' | binomial_authority = ([[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]) Roussel 1796 | synonyms = ''Suillus aeruginascens'' Secr. ex Snell
''Suillus laricinus'' (Berk.) Kuntze
''Ixocomus viscidus'' (Fr. & Hök) Quél. }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Suillus viscidus'' | whichGills = decurrent | capShape = convex | hymeniumType = pores | stipeCharacter = ring | ecologicalType = mycorrhizal | sporePrintColor = brown | howEdible = edible}} '''''Suillus viscidus''''' ([[common name|commonly known]] as the '''sticky bolete''') is an edible, uncommon [[mushroom]] in the genus ''[[Suillus]]''.{{cite book |title=Wild edible fungi: a global overview of their use and importance to people |last=Boa |first=E. R. |year=2004 |publisher=Food & Agriculture Org. |location= |isbn=978-92-5-105157-3 |page=139 |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Zd2NlcNZgvcC}} It associates with [[larch]] and is found throughout Europe and in Japan. ==Description== The [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] is hemispherical when young, later convex to flat, whitish grey or darker. It is up to 12 cm in diameter. It is slimy, and blotchy when old. The large, angular [[Hymenium|pores]] on the underside of the cap are coloured pallid to yellowish at first, but become darker with maturity. Yound specimens bear a whitish [[partial veil]] which soon shreds. The [[Hymenium|tubes]] are concolorous, and have a slightly decurrent stem attachment. The [[Stipe (mycology)|stem]] bears a thin, slimy, dark-coloured [[Annulus (mycology)|ring]] in the uppermost part of the stem which is sometimes lost in mature specimens. The stem is divided by the ring into a short lighter, yellowish section above, and a duller, greyish section below. The flesh is whitish-grey, very soft and has a mild or non-distinct taste.{{cite book |author=Garnweidner E. |title=Mushrooms and Toadstools of Britain and Europe |publisher=Collins |year=1994 }}{{cite book |author=Jordan M. |title=The Encyclopedia of Fungi of Britain and Europe |publisher=David & Charles |location=London |year=1995 |page=349 |isbn=0-7153-0129-2}} The [[spore]]s are clay-coloured and ellipsoid or subfusiform in shape. Their dimensions are 10-12 by 4-5.5 μm. It is an edible mushroom of low quality.{{cite book|author= Læssøe Th., Del Conte A. |year=1996|title=The Mushroom Book|publisher=Dorling Kindersley|page=214|isbn=0-7513-0258-9}} ==Habitat== ''Suillus viscidus'' forms an [[Mycorrhiza#Ectomycorrhiza|ectomycorrhizal]] association with [[larch]] (''Larix'') specifically, and its distribution is thus limited by the range of the host tree. It occurs throughout Europe, and also in Japan.{{cite web |url=http://www.ne.jp/asahi/mediart/takutaku/kinoko/i-sironum.htm |title=Shironumeriiguchi |language=Japanese |accessdate=2010-09-17}} In Europe, it is considered an uncommon to rare fungus and it is to be found in the same habitat as the common larch bolete, ''[[Suillus grevillei]]'', and also the rare ''[[Suillus tridentinus]]''. Fruiting bodies are found in groups among grass under larch, from summer to autumn. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== [[File:Suillus viscidus 1.jpg|thumb|left|A collection of ''Suillus viscidus'' from the Italian province of [[Trentino]] | alt=A collection of ''Suillus viscidus'' from the Italian province of Trento]] {{IndexFungorum|324347}}
